repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:    Vim9: ":\*" is not recognized as a range.
Solution:   Move recognizing "\*" into skip_range().

https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/3bd8de40b484d3617a19092d3cc036f8b4f3d51c

---

Despite the original commit title mentioning vim9, the change is unrelated and todo with fast-parsing/tab completion of the cmdline, skipping over [`:star-visual-range`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/cmdline.html#%3Astar-visual-range)

comment_regular_data.body:
Lint error is a file-size one:

> `FAIL: /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c (File size changed from 245016 to 245020)`
Lint error is due to missing braces.

Is this a partial patch, not a full patch?

```
commit 3bd8de40b484d3617a19092d3cc036f8b4f3d51c
Author: Bram Moolenaar <Bram@vim.org>
Date:   Mon Sep 14 16:37:34 2020 +0200

    patch 8.2.1679: Vim9: ":*" is not recognized as a range
    
    Problem:    Vim9: ":*" is not recognized as a range.
    Solution:   Move recognizing "*" into skip_range(). (closes #6838)

 src/cmdexpand.c               |  2 +-
 src/ex_docmd.c                | 11 +++++++----
 src/ex_getln.c                | 10 +++++++---
 src/proto/ex_docmd.pro        |  2 +-
 src/testdir/test_vim9_cmd.vim | 11 +++++++++++
 src/userfunc.c                |  2 +-
 src/version.c                 |  2 ++
 src/vim9compile.c             |  2 +-
 8 files changed, 31 insertions(+), 11 deletions(-)
```

001209a2fe25612f2fe076d2db3d3073f0a6e008 removed CPO_STAR yet code is still applicable for `skip_star`.

```diff
+    // Skip "*" used for Visual range.
+    if (skip_star && *cmd == '*' && vim_strchr(p_cpo, CPO_STAR) == NULL)
+       cmd = skipwhite(cmd + 1);
+
```

> Is this a partial patch, not a full patch?
> 
> ```
>  src/cmdexpand.c               |  2 +-
>  src/ex_docmd.c                | 11 +++++++----
>  src/ex_getln.c                | 10 +++++++---
>  src/proto/ex_docmd.pro        |  2 +-
>  src/testdir/test_vim9_cmd.vim | 11 +++++++++++
>  src/userfunc.c                |  2 +-
>  src/version.c                 |  2 ++
>  src/vim9compile.c             |  2 +-
>  8 files changed, 31 insertions(+), 11 deletions(-)
> ```
> 
> [001209a](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/001209a2fe25612f2fe076d2db3d3073f0a6e008) removed CPO_STAR yet code is still applicable for `skip_star`.

It's a full patch, just that 90% of the changes aren't relevant as they're plumbing for whether to skip the `*` - but that's only because in one case [vim wants to treat `*` as a command](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/93d9d196ed3a70174ba5e790d9e36e0478e84a09/src/userfunc.c#L1284-L1285=), which is no longer the case in neovim (so we don't need `skip_star`)

> but that's only because in one case [vim wants to treat `*` as a command](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/93d9d196ed3a70174ba5e790d9e36e0478e84a09/src/userfunc.c#L1284-L1285=), which is no longer the case in neovim (so we don't need `skip_star`)

I don't understand how you arrived at that conclusion.

> > but that's only because in one case [vim wants to treat `*` as a command](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/93d9d196ed3a70174ba5e790d9e36e0478e84a09/src/userfunc.c#L1284-L1285=), which is no longer the case in neovim (so we don't need `skip_star`)
> 
> I don't understand how you arrived at that conclusion.

I may well be wrong, here's my thinking:
1. The [original patch](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/3bd8de40b484d3617a19092d3cc036f8b4f3d51c) had two parts:
  - Fix `skip_range()` to skip over `*` (an alias for `'<,'>`)
  - Add a `skip_star` param to `skip_range` for when we want to treat `*` as a command (`:*`)
    - As [noted above](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/37052#issuecomment-3678427989), neovim removed this command
2. The one location where vim doesn't want to skip over `*` is in [`userfunc.c`](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/93d9d196ed3a70174ba5e790d9e36e0478e84a09/src/userfunc.c#L1284-L1285=):
> ```
> // Check for ":append", ":change", ":insert".  Not for :def.
> char_u *tp = p = skip_range(p, FALSE, NULL);
>                                ^^^^^
> ```

Here we're interested in the command (`append`, `change`, etc) and I believe the intent of not skipping `*` is to treat it as a command.

But since neovim doesn't have `:*`, this isn't relevant - we always want to treat `:*` as a range, so `skip_range`'s `skip_star` should always true (so we don't need the parameter and thus don't need the majority of the patch, just the bugfix for skipping `*`)

---

If you want to see the bug, in neovim enter the following:
`:*!gr<Tab>`
Note that no completion takes place.

With the bug fixed, neovim's completion recognises `*` as a range, skips it and the cmdline completes to:
`:*!grep `

> Here we're interested in the command (`append`, `change`, etc) and I believe the intent of not skipping `*` is to treat it as a command.

I don't think this is the case. In Vim, `*` is only treated as a command if `*` flag is in 'cpoptions', and the `vim_strchr(p_cpo, CPO_STAR) == NULL` condition in `skip_range()` already handles tat.

I have a theory that this is because in Vim9 script it's possible to break a `a * b` expression just before the `*` (in legacy Vim script the continuation line needs to start with `\`, but in Vim9 script that's not needed). I'm not sure how much sense this theory makes, given that `skip_expr()` still skips over `+`, but I don't have any better theory...

Ah, that does seem reasonable. Now I think about it, there's no mention of `*` in the [relevant part of `userfunc.c`](https://github.com/vim/vim/blob/93d9d196ed3a70174ba5e790d9e36e0478e84a09/src/userfunc.c#L1284-L1293) either, so perhaps it's not looking for the `*`-command. But like you say, `+` will be skipped, as will `-` and `%`.

Had a look through to see if I could find any rationale, but `skip_range()` looks to go back to [`v7.0001`](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/071d4279d6ab81b7187b48f3a0fc61e587b6db6c/), so the reason is likely lost to us (without unearthing older version history).

---

So I think that leaves us with the question: does this code need to skip a `*` ? If so, we add the parameter in, if not, this patch is ready, would you say?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/d1189ea508c888ebf7468be3872c975e4ea264bb/src/nvim/eval/userfunc.c#L2496-L2507

I would hazard a guess that skipping a star here is a historic artefact and passing `skip_star = false` here would be a bug, but I can't be certain.

I also think passing `skip_star = false` here would be a bug. Before this patch the following code leads to a strange error:
```vim
func Foo()
  call setline(1, range(1, 10))
  exe "normal! ggV2j\<Esc>"
  *python3 << trim EOF
    endfunc = vim.current.range
    print(endfunc.start, endfunc.end)
  EOF
endfunc
call Foo()
```
In the current state of this PR this no longer leads to an error, while in Vim the error still happens. I see no reason why this strange error has to be kept, unless Bram wants to discourage using `*` instead of `'<,'>` (like [why he wanted to keep some other error](https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/12325#issuecomment-1530118403)), which also seems unlikely as that's the opposite of what this patch does.
Nice repro - yeah I agree, I think it would be more obvious in code if the intention was to discourage a star-range too. I will add that repro (or similar) to the test suite if you like?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: vim-patch:8.2.1679: ":*" is not recognized as a range
